name: Kepler-310
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-310 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-310 is a star with 0.775 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.88 times its radius. It is located 1998.91 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-310 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-310 b

Kepler-310 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.11 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 13.93 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-310.

The mass of Kepler-310 b is 1.46 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-310 b is 1.19 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-310 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-310 c

Kepler-310 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.28 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 56.48 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-310.

The mass of Kepler-310 c is 17.95 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-310 c is 3.38 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-310 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

Kepler-310 d

Kepler-310 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.39 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 92.88 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-310.

The mass of Kepler-310 d is 8.39 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-310 d is 2.47 that of Earth. At 8.39 Earth masses, Kepler-310 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-310, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
